blocks.value: St. Thérèse of Lisieux (St. Teresa of the Child Jesus) was born in France in 1873. She entered the Carmelite convent at the young age of 15 and lived a hidden life of prayer and sacrifice.

St. Thérèse developed her "Little Way" of spiritual childhood, which emphasizes doing small things with great love, trusting in God's mercy, and surrendering completely to His will. Her autobiography, "Story of a Soul," has inspired millions.
St. Thérèse died of tuberculosis in 1897 at the age of 24. She was canonized in 1925 and declared a Doctor of the Church in 1997. She is one of the patron saints of missionaries and of France.
